On June 19, 1865, 250,000 slaves in Texas were freed and America took another step towards its promise of freedom for all. 
Today is #Juneteenth, when we commemorate the end of slavery in the United States and continue the work to eradicate racism.

It commemorates freedom, while acknowledging the sacrifices and contributions made by courageous African Americans towards making our great nation the more conscious and accepting country that it has become. Today marks the 155th anniversary of Juneteenth. (3/3)
Upon hearing the news of their freedom, they rejoiced that the prayers of generations had finally been answered. Juneteenth remains the oldest known celebration of slavery’s demise. (2/3)

On June 19, 1865, word of emancipation reached the last groups of enslaved African-Americans in Texas--nearly 2.5 years after slaves were freed in the Confederate States of America. (1/3) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ea2HaP5XkAIb205.png

Today we celebrate #Juneteenth, a date marking the liberation of slaves kept in captivity even after Lincoln’s emancipation proclamation. It is a day to acknowledge, and reflect on the experiences of African Americans and to celebrate the contributions of the black community.

RT @BizRoundtable We applaud @JacksonLeeTX18 for introducing a resolution that recognizes June 19, 2020 as this year’s observance of #Juneteenth2020, and join with @theblackcaucus in commemorating this momentous day for black Americans.

155 years ago today, the last slaves were freed following the end of the Civil War. #Juneteenth is about freedom, dignity, and the end of a terrible chapter in our nation’s history. If you don’t know, now you know.

Today, on #Juneteenth, we commemorate the end of slavery in the U.S. On June 19, 1865, the last forcibly enslaved Americans were freed, but the fight towards equality is still not over. This bill is an important step towards creating a system built on fairness and justice for Black Americans, and all Americans. I look forward to working with my colleagues in the Senate to reach a bipartisan deal.

Let me be clear: The Justice in Policing Act does not defund the police, but rather holds law enforcement accountable while improving community services and programs that have been neglected for decades.

Most importantly, the Justice in Policing Act will help communities reimagine public safety by investing in mental health & homeless services, rehabilitation, & vital programs, while helping local police focus on work we really need them for, which is keeping our streets safe.
This Justice in Policing Act would create a system of accountability and transparency in law enforcement and eliminate harmful practices like chokeholds and no-knock warrants.

While our local law enforcement agencies have taken important steps to build community trust and reform their use of force guidelines, there is definitely a need to do more to ensure transparency and accountability in policing from the federal level.
In recent weeks, I’ve spoken with leaders in the Black community, activists, and law enforcement about the right ways to fix our criminal justice system and improve policing:

And perhaps a good first step to changing attitudes toward racial discrimination would be for each of us who are white to ask ourselves this question: 

How would I feel if police in my hometown repeatedly stopped me for being a white man or a white woman in the wrong place?
I’m grateful that @SenatorTimScott gave me permission to tell his story.
So today, 155 years later, hopefully will encourage more victims of racism to tell their stories and more white Americans to adjust our attitudes.
I wonder how many white Americans know that things like that still happen today in 2020.

Tim Scott, who is an African American Republican senator from S.C., once told our Bible study that police in his hometown stopped him several times for being a “Black man in the wrong place,” even though at the time he was serving as Chairman of the Charleston County Council.
That long way to go will not be as easy as passing laws – although @SenatorTimScott’s JUSTICE Act, which I am cosponsoring, will definitely help. It will also take changing behavior.

The struggle for civil rights is not a snapshot—it is a panorama.  
As Benjamin Hooks, the former @NAACP president from Memphis, said that “America is a work in progress. We’ve come a long way, and we have a long way to go.”

And #Juneteenth carries more meaning this year than most, when millions across our country stand in defiance of police brutality and the murder of unarmed Black men and women.

It is again a time for change, a time for justice, a time for renewal.

#Juneteenth is a day of reverence for one of the most painful chapters in our history. But it’s also one of celebration, that speaks to good overcoming evil, of the righting of wrongs, of a new chapter, and a continual rebirth of our nation as we seek a more perfect union.
